emailColumn.title: e-rocket: Digital Tipping Vision in the MENA Market

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Michael Lvov is a co-founder of e-rocket, a digital tipping platform that attempted to expand from its home market to Dubai and the MENA region. E-rocket developed an online tipping solution for restaurants, allowing customers to tip service workers digitally, but faced significant challenges in achieving product-market fit in international markets.

materialsUsed: Mordor Intelligence. (2024). UAE Fintech Market Size. Market expected to reach USD 6.43 billion by 2030, growing at CAGR of 12.56%.
Fintechnews Middle East. (2025). UAE Fintech Report 2024. 329 active fintech companies, with 61.7% headquartered in Dubai.
Mordor Intelligence. (2024). MENA Digital Payments Market. Size estimated at USD 226.53 billion in 2024, expected to reach USD 380.86 billion by 2029.
Pew Research Center. (2025). Tipping Culture in America. 72% of U.S. adults say tipping is expected in more places than five years ago.
McKinsey. (2024). State of Consumer Digital Payments. Digital wallet in-store adoption increased from 19% in 2019 to 28% in 2024.

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.description: e-rocket's journey demonstrates that great ideas don't automatically translate to global success. Key lessons include: thorough market research is essential before expansion - surface-level analysis isn't enough; cultural differences in business practices can make or break expansion efforts; product-market fit in one region doesn't guarantee success elsewhere; the importance of understanding local business culture and sales cycles; having sufficient capital reserves for longer-than-expected market penetration timelines; and sometimes the right product in the wrong market at the wrong time won't succeed, regardless of execution quality.

emails.subject: Start point. Why Dubai?
emails.body:
Hope you're doing well. As for me, this time I'm heading to the US to Market Conference ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸. This is gonna be amazing! So many speakers are comingâ€¦ My flight is delayed âœˆï¸, so I have time to write you this letter.

I remember about our agreement and I start my story of e-rocket. So, let's begin! ğŸš€

Our product in Dubai was inspired by the story of online tipping at home ğŸ’¡. It seemed like a very simple, straightforward product that wasn't too time-consuming or complex to develop, and it provided value to everyone: the client leaving the tip ğŸ’°, the waiter receiving it ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ³, and so on.

In 2021, the home market was dying ğŸ“‰. There were four companies competing with each other. The only way they could compete was lowering transaction fees. At that point, these companies started being acquired by banks ğŸ¦. We realized we were already late, and there was no room for us. There was no real reason to enter the home market anymore. Plus, it's always about capitalization. There's no real venture capital market at home â€” it's minimal ğŸ’¸. We wanted to create a company with a high valuation internationally, with the possibility of selling it to a bank later. The basic scenario was either to build a clear, fast dividend business and earn passively from transaction fees, or to go the Net Monet routeâ€”conquering market share quickly and then selling to a strategic buyer or a large bank ğŸ¯.

We've conducted around 20 Zoom interviews with people from Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª, the UK ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§, the US ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, and Thailand ğŸ‡¹ğŸ‡­ (30-40 interviews in total) and realized that there were no real analogs to this product in the world, except at home. So, we started looking at where we could take this business model ğŸŒ.

We've chosen launching in the MENA region, exactly in Dubai, because:
It has a good tax system ğŸ“Š, it's a fast-growing region with a high average income and a large number of restaurants ğŸ½ï¸;
it's geographically convenient ğŸ—ºï¸;
It seemed to be easy to set up a company here and we could remotely and quickly set up operations and then expand globally from there ğŸŒ;
One of my co-founders was here, walking around restaurants, and noticed they were starting to digitizeâ€”they had just begun accepting Apple Pay ğŸ“±, for example.

I suppose it's enough for now. Have to go âœˆï¸.

highlight.title: When Home Market Dies, Look Global
highlight.description: Sometimes your local market becomes too competitive or gets taken over by big companies. That's when smart entrepreneurs look for new opportunities in other countries where their idea might work better and there's less competition.

emails.subject: The Strategy and the Plan
emails.body:
I arrived in NY yesterday ğŸ—½, visited some places. My hotel is near the conference hall ğŸ¨. I've already signed up for participation. Now I'm chilling ğŸ˜. You asked me if there was a plan or just "Let's see what happens and move forward"? Let me continue the story.

There was a clear plan, of course ğŸ“Š. Everything was sequential. First, open a company, come here, gather pre-sales, launch the product in parallel, and get the first transaction ğŸ’³. Then, go from zero to 20 restaurants and raise investments based on that ğŸ½ï¸. So, it was a pretty transparent, clear roadmap ğŸ—ºï¸.

Here's how it happened: we opened a company, and about a month later, we came to Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª.
We came initially as founders ğŸ‘¥.
So, we came for two weeks to do the paperwork ğŸ“„, and returned back to home. Then we came for a month, started selling, onboarding the first restaurant ğŸª, and so on. Then we returned to home again. And the third time, we came and stayed for a year ğŸ“…. By then, we had brought in the team, had our first clients, and started building operations. And then we realized we weren't planning to return to home ğŸ . So, we stayed there full-time. It was like the first two times were just to solve technical issues, and then we fully committed. You can't build a business in Dubai any other way ğŸ’¯.

We conducted remote CSOs and then... We didn't even have a product yet ğŸš§. We were developing the product in parallel, but we walked into restaurants with a Net Monet check, asking for the operations director, showing them the check, and saying, "What do you think?" ğŸ’­ Everyone said, "Great idea, we're ready to launch," and we walked through about 100 restaurants with the founder. But it turned out to be a lot of provocation because the Emirati market is specificâ€”they say "yes, yes," but it rarely leads to signing a contract ğŸ“. They don't know how to say no, they like everything, but it doesn't convert into sales ğŸ“‰. Out of the restaurants we visited, we only connected with about two.

The budget was all tied to investments because we received the first tranche of about half a million dollars ğŸ’°. So, we mapped out a roadmap, hired salespeople, account managers, marketers ğŸ‘¥, and so on, but it turned out that a lot of it didn't work. Cold calls worked for us ğŸ“. We hired telemarketers who scheduled meetings, and then the salespeople on the ground would come in and close the deals. That's what really worked âœ….

Now I end this letter, it's time to refuel â›½. There is a nice restaurant on the ground floor ğŸ½ï¸.

highlight.title: Having a Plan vs. Local Reality Check
highlight.description: It's great to have a clear step-by-step plan, but be ready for surprises! What works in one culture might not work in another. In some places, people say 'yes' to be polite, but that doesn't mean they'll actually buy your product.

emails.subject: The Team
emails.body:
How are you doing? ğŸ˜Š

You've asked me to tell more about the team I worked with, so here it is.

Well, first was an account manager who helped with onboarding restaurants ğŸªâ€”getting them onto the platform, handling communication ğŸ’¬, and so on.

Next, we hired a sales manager who built the sales team ğŸ“ˆ. The sales manager, I brought over from home ğŸ . The other guy was already in the UAE ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª, and we just happened to work well together ğŸ¤.

Our goal was to reach those who were ready ASAP âš¡. We started networking, looking for people on LinkedIn ğŸ’¼, Facebook ğŸ“˜, and Clubhouse ğŸ§. We reached out to whoever we could as quickly as possible. We drew a map of where we had connections ğŸ—ºï¸, who worked where, who had friends in the restaurant business ğŸ½ï¸, and so on. Based on that, we talked to them and gathered feedback ğŸ“.

There were no strict requirements for the staff ğŸ“‹. It was more about speed âš¡, and we hired people who had the skills: good English ğŸ—£ï¸, a background in sales ğŸ’¼, and the ability to learn quickly ğŸ§ . Because you're starting a business in a country where, at that point, we didn't know much about hiring employees ğŸ‘¥, where to do it, or how to pay salaries ğŸ’°. It was a minimal experience, and then we figured it out, but it took some time â°.

Later, our team became international ğŸŒâ€”we had people from India ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡³, Africa ğŸŒ. Now it's a mixed team ğŸ­.

We hired based on qualifications and what they could bring to the table ğŸ’ª. There was no preference for cheaper labor ğŸ’¸, but Dubai is a multinational city ğŸ™ï¸. We didn't look at nationality, just at their skills and ability to perform as we needed ğŸ¯. Everyone had good spoken and written English ğŸ—£ï¸. That was an important criterion. It was just a given that everything had to be in English ğŸŒ.

You know, English is a multicultural language, and I'll be speaking English at the conference, too ğŸ¤. I didn't tell you before, but I was invited to the conference as a speaker. I'm a bit nervous â˜ºï¸: there are plenty CIS businessmen ğŸ‘”.

highlight.title: Speed Over Perfect Planning in Hiring
highlight.description: When you're starting in a new country, sometimes you need to hire fast and figure things out as you go. Focus on finding people with the right skills and attitude, not perfect backgrounds. Being flexible and learning quickly is more important than having everything planned perfectly.

emails.subject: Smth goes wrong, a remarkable experience
emails.body:
It's time to tell about some sad things that happened to us ğŸ˜”. I now see it as a great experience for young founders and me, too. You asked me, when I started to understand that something wasn't working ğŸ¤”.

Realization that something wasn't working probably came around the third month when we weren't growing as fast as we planned ğŸ“‰, and there wasn't much momentum.

Then, as a startup, you have several hypotheses ğŸ’­â€”maybe we're a new brand, and they don't trust us ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸, or maybe the penetration is low, and we need to create a culture of online tipping ğŸ’³. And so on.

There was a point where we realized things weren't moving as planned ğŸ“Š, we weren't hitting KPIs, not even our internal goals ğŸ¯.

So, we thought, "Let's add this, test that, let's not just focus on restaurants but also beauty salons ğŸ’„. Let's not just collect tips but also reviews â­. Let's push reviews to Google Maps ğŸ—ºï¸." So, we started approaching it product-wise, adding various features iteratively ğŸ”„. Anyway, around 6-7 months gone â°, we objectively realized that as a standalone product it wasn't going to take off ğŸš€. So, we started adding... We went to restaurants, asked what their pain points were ğŸ˜«, what they wanted to add, and started developing other products based on that feedback ğŸ’¡.

For this, I think, it's important to understand that you can't really test this remotely ğŸŒ. Remote case studies are useless because they don't lead to contracts ğŸ“. If I had signed contracts over calls â˜ï¸, then it would have worked. So, we started following a model where we sell something first, then implement and sell it differently ğŸ”„.

But it doesn't work otherwise. Because they'll say something nice, say, "Yes, interesting," but when it comes to the contract, it just doesn't convert ğŸ“‰. Plus, you have to understand the specifics of the Emirati marketâ€”everything takes a long time â°, the sales system doesn't work like at home or Europe because they don't have a culture of saying no ğŸ™…â€â™‚ï¸, they're very afraid of making reputational decisions. Dubai is a city where people come and go ğŸšª; it's easy to set up a company, take the money, and leave ğŸ’¸. And their management doesn't think in terms of metrics ğŸ“Š, where you come in, and the manager says, "Guys, I need to increase the average check ğŸ’°. What can you offer?" Or, "I have a large customer base ğŸ‘¥, but I'm not doing anything with it. Do you have a solution?" ğŸ’¡

Well, got to go now âœˆï¸. Prepare all the stuff for my presentation ğŸ“Š.

highlight.title: When Things Don't Work, Pivot Fast
highlight.description: Sometimes your original idea just won't work in a new market, and that's okay! The key is recognizing it quickly and trying different approaches. Don't be afraid to change your product based on what customers actually want, not what you think they need.

emails.subject: The Plan vs Reality
emails.greeting: Hey, Antony, that was a great conference!
emails.body:
Really cool experience! I've got new precious contacts and ideas and so on ğŸ¤. I have some free time before going to the conference closing ceremony ğŸŠ, so let's finish the e-rocket story. You've asked me if the plan was based on something we did in the home market (like Nochka or others) or if it was a specific plan for Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª.

I can tell that the first financial model we drew up was, of course, based on Nochka ğŸ“Š, which managed to connect 13-15 thousand restaurants in three years ğŸ½ï¸. Then we underestimate ourselves ğŸ˜….

First, it turned out that Dubai and the UAE are a relatively small market ğŸ“â€”about 20 thousand restaurants, compared to 200 thousand at home ğŸ . And it turned out that they weren't that quick to adopt technology ğŸ“±.

Later, if we jump ahead â­ï¸, we didn't achieve product-market fit with the online tipping technology ğŸ’³. If there wasn't rapid market conquest ğŸš€, we changed the model, tested different hypotheses ğŸ§ª, reconfigured the system, like payment systems ğŸ’°, and so on. But it turned out that, as a standalone product, online tipping didn't spread as quickly in the UAE ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª.

It's not that we failed âŒ, but over time, because we were the first to launch this and probably the fastest âš¡, especially when the war started âš”ï¸, other teams came in trying to follow the same path, but everyone failed, and no one succeeded ğŸ˜”.

It's not a mistakeâ€”it just turned out to be the wrong market, wrong timing â°. We didn't achieve product-market fit ğŸ¯. We had a hypothesis that, I'd say, wasn't confirmed âŒ. That's the right way to put it. Because we're a startup ğŸš€, we set hypotheses, and this one didn't work out.

Probably, the right move would have been to enter with a different product from the start ğŸ”„. After several iterations, we arrived at what we're doing now, and we realized we should have either launched a different product or entered a different market ğŸŒ. Right away, probably the US market ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, because it's more capitalized ğŸ’°, has a developed venture ecosystem ğŸ¦, and is statistically larger ğŸ“Š. But if we're talking about MENA ğŸŒ, it's a big market tooâ€”there's Saudi Arabia ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¦, Egypt ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡¬, which also have good potential ğŸ“ˆ.

If you have any more questions, let me know â“.

Hope to see you soon! ğŸ‘‹

highlight.title: Wrong Market, Wrong Time - That's Okay!
highlight.description: Sometimes even a great idea just doesn't fit the market you chose, and that's not your fault! Even if other companies try the same thing and also fail, it might just mean the timing or market wasn't right. The important thing is learning from it and trying somewhere else.
